Unnamed Group of People.Sourced Statement: Participants report feeling more free to spend money on self care, outings with family members or sharing their wealth with community members.
Unnamed Group of People.Source Justification: Participants in the Breathe program report feeling more free to spend money on self care, outings with family members or sharing their wealth with community members.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: "With all the struggling I was doing, my attitude took a hit," Kahlia said. "The more you witness yourself being down and out, the more you feel down and out, and the more stuck you feel."
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Kipp Kahlia, a participant in the Breathe program, shares her experience of feeling stuck due to health issues and financial struggles.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: "It’s taking me from always putting out fires to being able to actually make some moves to advance, not just being stuck," Kahlia said.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Kipp Kahlia, a participant in the Breathe program, describes how the program has helped her move forward.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: "I didn’t expect to be accepted," to the Breathe program, Kahlia said. "When I was, I was really, really pleasantly surprised. It definitely took the edge off."
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Kipp Kahlia, a participant in the Breathe program, shares her surprise and relief at being accepted into the program.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: "I’m probably getting more comfortable with spending money," she said. "Just learning to say yes to stuff. There’s some stuff that, at the beginning of the program I felt was, you know, almost extravagant. And now I’m like ‘Oh my god, I really needed that for my business to move forward.’"
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Kipp Kahlia, a participant in the Breathe program, discusses how her spending habits have changed since joining the program.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: "I haven’t gotten to the sexy part yet," Kahlia said. "I had to get stronger and healthier, clear space, and lay a foundation first. Pulling yourself out of a hole often doesn’t look dramatic. For me it’s been the ability to do some fairly tedious stuff over an extended period of time, over and over again."
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Kipp Kahlia, a participant in the Breathe program, reflects on the progress she has made and the challenges she has faced.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: "Whenever L.A. city or county or Chicago or New York do something bold like this, it’s a really important signal that this big policy idea found its footing during COVID and represents a possible way forward in terms of supporting low income people across America," Kline said.
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: Director of the Stanford Basic Income Lab
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Sean Kline, director of the Stanford Basic Income Lab, discusses the significance of the Breathe program and its potential impact on low-income individuals.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: "If you knew the money was coming for three years, it’s a much longer runway. Can you go back to school? Can you quit your job now and look for a new one? Can you care for your aging parents?"
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: Director of the Stanford Basic Income Lab
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Sean Kline, director of the Stanford Basic Income Lab, poses questions about the potential long-term benefits of the Breathe program.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: "There is so much we don’t know yet," Castro said. "We don’t know how long people need to receive cash to create what level of change."
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: Director of Penn’s Center for Guaranteed Income Research
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Amy Castro, director of Penn’s Center for Guaranteed Income Research, discusses the uncertainties surrounding the impact of guaranteed income programs.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: "People need help with normal, everyday interactions that may be easy for some individuals," he said. "But for others, they don’t have any prior experience with them."
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Brian Arredondo, a coach for program participants, explains the challenges some participants face with everyday tasks.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: "It can’t just be the money," Fournier said. "It’s the opportunity and the access to experiences sometimes that really make a big difference when there is even a little bit more resources folks can have."
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: Overseer of the program coaches at Strength Based Community Change
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Ely Fournier, who oversees the program coaches at Strength Based Community Change, emphasizes the importance of opportunities and experiences in addition to financial support.

Named Organization Sources.Sourced Statement: The pilot program will allow researchers to track its impact in a large, diverse region, said Sean Kline, director of the Stanford Basic Income Lab, which studies guaranteed income programs across the country.
Named Organization Sources.Source Justification: The Stanford Basic Income Lab studies guaranteed income programs across the country and provides insights into the Breathe program.

Named Organization Sources.Sourced Statement: Researchers at the University of Pennsylvania are surveying the 1,000 Breathe participants, along with a control group of people not receiving funds.
Named Organization Sources.Source Justification: Researchers at the University of Pennsylvania are conducting surveys to study the impact of the Breathe program.

Named Organization Sources.Sourced Statement: The program’s coaches, provided through Wilmington-based Strength Based Community Change, personally support participants as their lives change.
Named Organization Sources.Source Justification: Strength Based Community Change provides coaches who support participants in the Breathe program.
